page.title: 01GENERAL INTRODUCTION
page.content: The area is mainly rural with one large village, Peasedown St John, (population approx. 4000) surrounded by three smaller villages, Shoscombe to S.E., Camerton to W. and Carlingcott to N.W. The three smaller villages are all mentioned in the original Domesday Book. Peasedown origanally got its name for being the place they grew peas. The town developed as a result of coal mining, being surrounded by pits. The Roman Road "The Fosse Way" (now the A367) diagonally bisects the block and is the main commuter route to Bath. Apart from farming there is very little local employment, so the majority of the working population commute to Bristol or Bath.
